topic.name: Fieldwork Enquiry
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Fieldwork Enquiry in Geography

objectives.objective_text: Identify mistakes in the counting or measuring.
Identify an 'anomaly' (something that doesn't fit).
Identify dangers like cars or deep water.
Listen to safety rules.
List potential hazards before going outside.
Spot a simple pattern.
Conduct a simple survey (asking people questions).
Ask a simple question about the outdoors (e.g., 'How many trees are there?').
Write a question that can be answered by counting or measuring.
Formulate a simple hypothesis ('I think there will be more...').
Collect both quantitative (numbers) and qualitative (words/feelings) data.
Make a Pictogram (using pictures for numbers).
Say which had the most or least.
Answer the starting question.
Share what was learned.
Describe the trends in the graph (going up or down).
Explain why the results happened.
Write a paragraph summarizing the answer.
Draw a reasoned conclusion supported by evidence.
Defend the conclusion against alternative explanations.
Count things and use tally marks.
Take pictures of what we see.
Draw a picture of the place.
Collect leaves or rocks (if allowed).
Use a thermometer or rain gauge.
Record data in a pre-made table.
Use 'Random Sampling' (picking spots by chance).
Use technical equipment (clinometer, flow meter) correctly.
Perform complex measurements (infiltration rates, sediment analysis).
Draw a bar chart with blocks.
Show the collection on a table.
Draw a sketch of the area.
Label axes correctly.
Draw a field sketch with labels.
Use a pie chart for percentages.
Draw a Desire Line map or Flow Line map.
Annotate photographs to highlight geographical features.
Use digital tools to create professional charts.
Defend the clarity and accuracy of the presentation.
Say what went well.
Say what was hard.
Think of a better way to do it next time.
Decide if the guess was right.
Explain how the weather or time of day changed things.
Suggest one improvement for the method.
Discuss if the results are true.
Defend the significance of the study despite limitations.
Wonder why something is where it is.
Choose a topic to look at (like birds or cars).
Make a guess about what we will find.
Decide what data is needed to answer the question.
Plan a sequence for the investigation.
Differentiate between descriptive and explanatory questions.
Develop a null hypothesis for a geographical study.
Justify the choice of study location.
Defend the scope of the enquiry against practical constraints.
Stay with the group/partner.
Wear the right clothes for the weather.
Suggest ways to stay safe (mitigation).
Check the weather forecast.
Understand the 'Buddy System'.
Plan emergency procedures.
Defend the decision to proceed or cancel based on safety.
Analyze the relationship between variables (correlation).
Interpret the mean, median, and mode of the data.
Connect the findings to geographical theory.
Analyze the difference between Random, Systematic, and Stratified sampling.
Analyze the reliability (repeatability) of the data.
Interpret the validity (did we measure what we wanted?).
Connect equipment limitations to errors.
Analyze the likelihood and severity of risks.
Evaluate the strength of the correlation.
Evaluate the sample size needed for statistical validity.
Evaluate the most appropriate graphical method for the data type.
Critique the sampling strategy.
Evaluate the impact of bias on the results.
Evaluate the feasibility of a fieldwork hypothesis.
Evaluate the ethics of working in a specific environment.
Evaluate dynamic risks while in the field.
Synthesize primary data collection with secondary data sources.
Construct a statistical analysis (Spearman's Rank, Chi-Squared).
Synthesize the findings into a formal report.
Design a questionnaire to avoid bias.
Construct a rigorous sampling strategy to minimize bias.
Create a neat Bar Chart or Line Graph.
Construct complex graphs (Scatter graphs, Histograms).
Construct sophisticated visualizations (Kite diagrams, Rose charts).
Synthesize data into infographic summaries.
Construct a critical review of the entire methodology.
Synthesize lessons learned for future research.
Construct a SMART enquiry question (Specific, Measurable, etc.).
Construct a complex research proposal.
Synthesize previous research to inform the enquiry question.
Create a formal Risk Assessment table.
Construct a professional Risk Assessment and Management plan.
Synthesize legal and ethical responsibilities in fieldwork.
